sect2.title: Location-Speakers
sect2.para: Varieties and subdialects of Oromo are spoken by millions of individuals over much of central and southern Ethiopia . The variety treated here is characteristic of the west-central region, specifically Wallagga. Other more-or-less distinct varieties are the Eastern , Borana-Arsi-Guji, and Orma (spoken in Kenya).

table.caption: The following lexical items are used in the verbal paradigms:

sect1.title: Morphosyntactic Properties
sect1.para: Oromo paradigms employ the following property-value dimenstions

listitem.para: Oromo follows the Cushitic-Omotic PNG Pattern

itemizedlist.title: Verb Properties
itemizedlist.para:
General Characterization: In the affirmative main clause, Oromo makes the usual simple tense distinctions. The non-compound categories present/past, affirmative/negative, and main/subordinate interact in the following complex way, illustrated in the table below. In the present affirmative, the main clause PNG suffixes have a characteristic -a vocalization as opposed to a -u vocalization in the subordinate. In the present negative, the mainClause forms have the same -u PNG series as the subordinate main; the present negative subordinate has an invariant -ne PNG suffix. In the past tense, there is no distinction between main and subordinate forms. The affirmative past tense has an -e PNG vocalization, while the negative main and subordinate now has the invariant -ne.The following table illustrates the distribution of PNG+tense markers, where the PNG sequence is: 1sg, 2sg, 3msg, 3fsg, 1pl, 2pl, 3pl (i.e., the Cushitic-Omotic Pattern):
Tense Affirmative Negative
Main Subordinate Main Subordinate
Present -a -u -u -ne
-ta -tu -tu
-a -u -u
-ti -tu -tu
-na -nu -nu
-tu -tani/u -tani/u
-u -ani/u -ani/u
Past -e -ne
-te
-e
-te
-ne
-tan(i)
-an(i)
In the compound tenses Oromo makes characteristic distinctions of tense and aspect (perfectivity and progressivity) as described in documentation guide, and indicated here, as usual. by approximate glosses.

listitem.para: affirmative: if "emphatic" or foregrounded, can be preceeded by proclitic (h)Ã­n- in present tense.
negative: takes negative proclitic ((h)i)n-, plus special negative tenses, as described above. When reduced to simple segment -n-, the particle can be encliticized to preceeding word.
futurePerfect. Structure:V[infinitive]+f+tur-[past] Gloss: "he will have gone, . . ."
BE: Oromo has an uninflected enclitic for the simple positive (-Éa) and negative (-miti) copula. Otherwise for BE it uses suppletively the following verbs:
ta-: predication, non-past/non-present; occurrence, all tenses

sect1.title: Attested Archive Paradigms
sect1.para:
The following two tables give the feature-value combinations of the paradigms wich are actually documented in the archive. The first simply lists the shared property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The second listing gives a spreadsheet-like row-by-column enumeration for the properties which are common to each paradigm; this eventually should be user-sortable to facilitate the comparative study of the paradigms. The second simply lists the common property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The abbreviation "PNG" in the paradigm variable-value lists stnads for:
gender:f,m,â¤ number:pl,sg person:p1,p2,p3
I.e., the PNG combinations normal with finite tam-forms.Clicking on the paradigmLabel will yield a display of the paradigm in question [either by link to hard-coded term cluster, or canned SPARQL query].
